channel.title: math.GN updates on arXiv.org
channel.description: math.GN updates on the arXiv.org e-print archive.

item.title: Algebraic $K$-theory of stably compact spaces
item.description: arXiv:2602.18245v1 Announce Type: cross Abstract: We compute the value of finitary localizing invariants, including algebraic $K$-theory, on categories of sheaves over stably locally compact spaces $X$. Our formula simultaneously generalizes the cases of locally compact Hausdorff and coherent (spectral) spaces and recovers several smaller $K$-theory calculations as special instances.
item.dc:creator: Georg Lehner

item.title: Machine Space I: Weak exponentials and quantification over compact spaces
item.description: arXiv:2209.11339v5 Announce Type: replace Abstract: Topology may be interpreted as the study of verifiability, where opens correspond to semi-decidable properties. In this paper we make a distinction between verifiable properties themselves and processes which carry out the verification procedure. The former are simply opens, while we call the latter machines. Given a frame presentation $\mathcal{O} X = \langle G \mid R\rangle$ we construct a space of machines $\Sigma^{\Sigma^G}$ whose points are given by formal combinations of basic machines corresponding to generators in $G$. This comes equipped with an `evaluation' map making it a weak exponential with base $\Sigma$ and exponent $X$. When it exists, the true exponential $\Sigma^X$ occurs as a retract of machine space. We argue this helps explain why some spaces are exponentiable and others not. We then use machine space to study compactness by giving a purely topological version of Escard\'o's algorithm for universal quantification over compact spaces in finite time. Finally, we relate our study of machine space to domain theory and domain embeddings.
item.dc:creator: Peter F. Faul, Graham Manuell

item.title: Center of distances of ultrametric spaces generated by labeled trees
item.description: arXiv:2601.13363v2 Announce Type: replace Abstract: The center of distances of a metric space $(X,d)$ is the set $C(X)$ of all $t\in \mathbb R^+$ for which the equation $d(x,p)=t$ has a solution for each $p\in X$. We prove that the equalities $C(X)=\{0\}$ or $C(X)=\{0,\operatorname{diam}X\} $ hold if $(X,d)$ is an ultrametric space generated by labeled trees. The necessary and sufficient conditions under which $\operatorname{diam} X\in C(X)$ are found.
item.dc:creator: Oleksiy Dovgoshey, Olga Rovenska
